awd_titl_txt: CCF- Algorithmic Foundations:  Motion Planning for Geometrically Constrained Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
Linkage reconfiguration problems underlie modern mathematical investigations in robotics, mechanical design, structural engineering, and bio-geometry, and have the potential of impacting computational biology, especially the problems emerging from modeling protein folding or, more generally, protein flexibility and motion.

This proposal focuses on the foundations of motion planning approaches to geometrically constrained structures.  The selected problems are part of a long-term program for understanding the combinatorial, rigidity-theoretic, algebraic and algorithmic aspects of a variety of motion planning approaches to geometric reconfiguration questions.  It builds upon the PIs' previous work on: (a) applying concepts from Rigidity Theory to 2-dimensional (2D) linkage reconfiguration problems (such as the Carpenter's Rule problem using pointed pseudo-triangulation), (b)  Combinatorial Rigidity (generalizations of Pebble Game algorithms for 2D-rigidity to other classes of matroidal sparse graphs, computation of rigid and stressed clusters), (c) motion generation (for pseudo-triangulations in 2D and for complex structures with many loops in 3D), and (d) recent results on finding extremal configurations of revolute jointed robotic manipulators. 

The proposal aims at developing systematic motion planning approaches, using mathematically proven techniques and exploiting discrete underlying structures of the geometrically constrained systems under investigation.  Examples include expansive motions and pseudo-triangulations, motion and reconfiguration for 3D-structures (linkages, panel-and-hinge and polyhedral structures) and reconfigurations of robot arms towards extremal configurations (minima and maxima), together with a theoretical investigation of their 3D workspace.

por.por_cntn:
Research outcomes:  The project focused on mathematical and algorithmic properties of several classes of geometrically constrained structures which are inspired by, and have applications in the study of complex biological macromolecules (proteins, DNA, RNA), biological assemblies (viruses) and crystalline matter, as well as in robotics (robot arms). The geometric models range from polygonal chains, mechanical bar-and-joint frameworks, structures with symmetry and periodicity to paneled surfaces inspired by creased origami shapes. 

The key results include: (a) a surprisingly efficient and accurate algorithm for computing the extremal reaches and the workspace of revolute jointed robot arms with concurrent consecutive hinges, and an efficient method for tracing their singularity locus. In particular, these results pave the way for efficient path planning algorithms and for simplified collision detection methods. (b) a foundational deformation theory of periodic frameworks, with applications in crystallography and materials science. This led to the first rigorous mathematical formulation of rigidity and flexibility for periodical deformations, and to new and efficient algorithms for detecting motion parameters such as periodic degrees of freedom. (c) a freely available web application and software infrastructure for studying the flexibility of biological macromolecules (proteins, DNA and RNA), based on these geometric models and implementing our algorithms, some of which were developed under previous grants. (d) a rigorous formulation of rigidity properties of Lang's universal molecule origami designs.

Relevance outside the discipline: The work on robotic arms has direct applications to robotics, nano-robotics and molecular biology. Rigidity of origami designs has applications in engineering, in the quest for designing deployable structures. The work on periodic structures has direct applications to crystallography and material sciences. The development of software facilitates the transfer of the mathematical and algorithmic ideas to the application areas. The models and algorithms studied under this grant are anticipated to lead to extensions of the software for computational molecular biology KINARI (http://kinari.cs.umass.edu) developed in the PIs group, which provides tools for studying challenging questions related to proteins (protein structure, flexibility and folding) and other macro-molecules. In turn, this has a potential use in the pharmaceutical field (rational drug design, vectors for drug delivery), thus potentially affecting medicine and public health. 

This project was carried out with students and collaborators from Rider University in New Jersey and Kyoto University in Japan. It provided research experiences to undergraduate students from the all-women Smith College and trained graduate students from the University of Massachusetts Amherst. It led to the development of additional educational materials and software available through the  LinkageLab web site of the PIs research group at http://linkage.cs.umass.edu.
